comments.author: Outhue
comments.body: Twitter need some answering to do, this platform doesn't care about nailing fake links and impersonators, honestly, Twitter is the most dangerous place for any crypto investors vs Telegram, on Telegram you are going go get PMed and that's purely wrong and suspicious but on Twitter, you really can't tell the difference some times, you need to watch your steps carefully and think before making any move, this is bad, I have blocked 100s of accounts tagging me for fake airdrops on Twitter and it's still counting, I may have to shut down my Twitter account in the end, this is getting too much and find other ways to stay informed about the projects that I am monitoring and following, I know these scammers are everywhere, even on Facebook and Discord but Twitter is too much.

comments.author: Mpamaegbu
comments.body: Quote from: Outhue on April 15, 2023, 09:56:28 AMTwitter is the most dangerous place for any crypto investors vs Telegram, on Telegram you are going go get PMed and that's purely wrong and suspicious but on Twitter, you really can't tell the difference some times...In the past, I participated in social media bounties here and that had me experiencing so many obvious scam projects, false airdrops and promotions. Like you said, it's easier to identify scams on Telegram than on Twitter but both are headquarters of fraud. Yes,scammers are often in a haste on Telegram, so their impatience will make them private chat their targets and that's a red flag. On Twitter, scammers just drop links and then wait for their traps to catch their preys. They don't rush. For me, I don't take anything crypto investment or giveaway on Twitter seriously any more.

comments.author: Ryker1
comments.body: Thank you for sharing this but for me --this is not new when it comes to this social media like Twitter and Telegram. As far as I know, if I am right Twitter has implemented measures to detect and remove fake accounts, and has also rolled out a verification process for high-profile accounts to help users identify right or legit sources of information --and also Twitter has partnered with the various organizations to promote digital literacy and raise awareness about scams and other forms of fraudulent activity. Better to stay away from those airdrops and bounties that lead to this scam attempt.

comments.author: elevates
comments.body: Never believe in social media news. Most of the time they are fake. I am not suprised that scammers were able to trend this hashtag. In the past they were able to hack accounts of celebrities. A lot needs to be changed by the new owner. The biggest issue on Twitter is fake news. We might have seen this happening for a DEX but it is quite common on that platform. A lot fake news was trended during the time of pandemic. Some of you might remember those incidents.
